raw_text:
Gadget show heralds MP3 Christmas
 
 Partners of those who love their hi-tech gear may want to get their presents in early as experts predict a gadget shortage this Christmas.
 
 With Apple's iPod topping wish lists again, there may not be enough iPod minis to go round, predicts Oliver Irish, editor of gadget magazine Stuff. "The iPod mini is likely to be this year's Tracey Island," said Mr Irish. Stuff has compiled a list of the top 10 gadgets for 2004 and the iPod is at number one.
 
 For anyone bewildered by the choice of gadgets on the market, Stuff and What Hi-Fi? are hosting a best-of gadget show in London this weekend. Star of the show will be Sony's Qrio Robot, an all-singing, all-dancing, football-playing man-machine who can even hold intelligent conversations.
 
 But he is not for sale and Sony has no commercial plans for the robot. "He will greet visitors and is flying in from Japan. He probably has his own airplane seat, that is how highly Sony prize him," said Mr Irish. Also on display will be a virtual keyboard which projects itself onto any flat surface. The event will play host to a large collection of digital music players, from companies such as Creative, Sony and Philips as well as the ubiquitously fashionable iPod from Apple. Suggestions that it could be a gaming or wireless Christmas are unlikely to come true as MP3 players remain the most popular stocking filler, said Mr Irish. "Demand is huge and Apple has promised that it can supply enough but people might struggle to get their hands on iPod minis," said Mr Irish.
 
 For those who like their gadgets to be multi-talented, the Gizmondo, a powerful gaming console with GPS and GPRS, that also doubles up as an MP3 player, movie player and camera, could be a must-have. "What is impressive is how much it can do and how well it can do them," said Mr Irish. This Christmas, gadgets will not be an all-male preserve. "Women will be getting gadgets from husbands and boyfriends as well as buying them for themselves," said Mr Irish. "Gadgets nowadays are lifestyle products rather than just for geeks."
llama3.2:1b: Apple's iPod may run out of minis this Christmas, predicted by gadget magazine Stuff editor Oliver Irish. The event will feature Sony Qrio Robot, an all-singing robot that can hold conversations and play football, and a virtual keyboard that projects onto surfaces. Other gadgets on display include digital music players from Creative, Sony, and Philips, as well as the iPod, Gizmondo gaming console with GPS and GPRS capabilities.
llama3.2:3b: Apple's iPod is predicted to have a high demand this Christmas, possibly leading to a shortage of iPod minis. A gadget show in London will feature various digital music players, including Sony's Qrio Robot, which is not for sale. Other popular gadgets include the Gizmondo gaming console with multiple functions and virtual keyboards that project themselves onto flat surfaces.
gemma2:2b: A gadget shortage is predicted this Christmas, with the iPod mini likely to be in high demand.  The Stuff and What Hi-Fi? event will showcase popular gadgets like the Qrio Robot from Sony and a virtual keyboard.   MP3 players remain the most sought-after gift, potentially resulting in difficulties obtaining limited stock of the iPod mini. The Gizmondo offers multiple functions as a gaming console, MP3 player, movie player, and camera. Women are increasingly buying or receiving tech gadgets for themselves.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A gadget show is coming up in the UK this Christmas. Some of the best gadgets being shown include a robot man-machine who can play football, a digital music player with a virtual keyboard and MP3 players becoming more popular again.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Apple's iPod tops wish lists, but shortage predicted this Christmas due to popularity of MP3 players; gadget show featuring Sony Qrio Robot, virtual keyboard, and digital music players including iPods from Apple and others; multi-talented Gizmondo gaming console doubles as MP3 player, movie player, and camera; women also buying gadgets for themselves.
qwen2.5:3b: Gadget show predicts a shortage of MP3 players this Christmas, with the iPod at top of wish lists. Sony's Qrio Robot will be featured, but not available for purchase. Virtual keyboards and multi-talented gadgets like the Gizmondo are also expected to be popular. Demand is high for Apple's iPod minis, suggesting supply issues. Women are expected to buy more gadgets as gifts or for personal use, reflecting their growing popularity beyond tech enthusiasts.

Partners of those who love their hi-tech gear may want to get their presents in early as experts predict a gadget shortage this Christmas.

With Apple's iPod topping wish lists again, there may not be enough iPod minis to go round, predicts Oliver Irish, editor of gadget magazine Stuff. The iPod mini is likely to be this year’s Tracey Island, said Mr Irish. Stuff has compiled a list of the top 10 gadgets for 2004 and the iPod is at number one.

For anyone bewildered by the choice of gadgets on the market, Stuff and What Hi-Fi? are hosting a best-of gadget show in London this weekend. Star of the show will be Sony’s Qrio Robot, an all-singing, all-dancing, football-playing man-machine who can even hold intelligent conversations.

But he is not for sale and Sony has no commercial plans for the robot. He probably has his own airplane seat, that is highly Sony-priced. Also on display will be a virtual keyboard which projects itself onto any flat surface. The event will play host to a large collection of digital music players, from Creative, Sony and Philips as well as the iPod from Apple.

Suggestions that it could be a gaming or wireless Christmas are unlikely to come true as MP3 players remain the most popular gadget, said Mr Irish. "Demand is huge and Apple has promised that it can supply enough but people might struggle to get their hands on iPod minis," said Mr Irish.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and to the point, capturing the main ideas and key details of the original text. It does not provide any explanations or reasoning processes, only presenting the information in a clear and straightforward manner. The summary stays true to the tone and style of the original text, with no added or removed words.

It mentions an MP3 Christmas event where gadgets are all about style and function, with Apple showing their latest product, the iPod mini. Oliver Irish from Stuff magazine predicted a gadget shortage because of this new model, and he called it "Tracey Island."

Then there's another show in London featuring Qrio Robot, a robot that can talk, hold intelligent conversations, and even sing. This robot isn't for sale, and Sony doesn't have plans for commercial use yet. The event is showcasing digital music players from various brands, including Creative, Philips, and the popular iPod.

The text also points out that demand is high but supply might be limited by competition. It mentions MP3 players being the biggest selling point. Another gadget mentioned is What Hi-Fi?, a gaming console with GPS, GPRS, MP3 player, movie player, and camera. These are lifestyle products meant for people who want to use tech for more than just gaming.

The summary should keep key points: the show's theme on gadgets as style and function, the main gadgets like iPod mini, Qrio Robot, virtual keyboard, digital music players, what hi-fi?, MP3 players, and that these are lifestyle products. I need to make sure I include all these without losing any important details.

I also have to keep it concise, avoiding any extra information or explanations beyond summarizing the key points. So, each main gadget should be highlighted, along with how gadgets are seen as versatile tools for people's lives.
</think>

A gizmondo, a powerful gaming console that doubles as an MP3 player and movie player, could be a must-have for tech enthusiasts. This year’s gadgets will revolve around style and functionality, with Apple showcasing the iPod mini again and Qrio Robot, a robot capable of intelligent conversation and dancing. However, Sony has no plans for its robot to be sold commercially. The show also features digital music players from companies like Creative, Philips, and the popular iPod, as well as what hi-fi?, a gaming console with GPS, GPRS, MP3 player, movie player, and camera. Demand is high but supply may be limited, especially since both Apple and Sony are focusing on MP3 players. This year’s gadgets will appeal to those who want to use tech for more than just gaming. Women will get gadgets from their husbands, girlfriends, or even buy them for themselves, reflecting the growing trend towards lifestyle products over just gaming.

It is also mentioned that there could be demand for MP3 players even though Apple has promised to meet it. The discussion also touches on how popular these gadgets have become and how they are likely to be used in the upcoming Christmas season.
phi:2.7b: Gadget Show heralds MP3 Christmas, with the iPod mini topping wish lists again due to a predicted shortage of iPod minis this year. Stuff magazine predicts that the iPod mini is likely to be "this year's Tracey Island" and has compiled a list of the top 10 gadgets for 2004. The show in London will feature Sony's Qrio Robot and a virtual keyboard which projects itself onto any flat surface. MP3 players remain the most popular stocking filler this Christmas, with Apple promising to supply enough but people may struggle to get their hands on iPod minis. The Gizmondo, a powerful gaming console with GPS and GPRS, is also a must-have gadget this year. Gadgets are not just for geeks any longer and women will be getting them from husbands, boyfriends, and buying them for themselves.

A gadget show in London will feature popular devices such as Sony's Qrio Robot and a virtual keyboard. The Gizmondo, a powerful gaming console, is also on display as a multi-talented device. Some popular gadgets this Christmas are predicted to be cameras, GPS devices, and music players.
hermes3:3b: Ipod mini shortage expected for Christmas; Gadget show highlights popular gadgets like iPod, Sony's Qrio robot, virtual keyboard.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Experts predict a gadget shortage this Christmas due to high demand for MP3 players, particularly the iPod mini. To help with choosing the best gadgets, Stuff and What Hi-Fi? are hosting a best-of gadget show in London featuring Sony's Qrio Robot and various digital music players from companies like Creative, Sony, Philips, and Apple. While some suggest that MP3 players could become gaming or wireless devices for Christmas, demand remains high for traditional MP3 players, causing potential struggles to obtain iPod minis. Multi-talented gadgets, such as the Gizmondo, a powerful gaming console with GPS and GPRS capabilities, are also gaining popularity.

MP3 players remain the most popular gifts, despite competition from gaming and wireless devices. The Gizmondo, a multifunctional gaming console, is also expected to be a hit. Gadgets are increasingly seen as lifestyle products, appealing to both men and women.

The article predicts a gadget shortage this Christmas due to Apple's iPod being at the top of wish lists, with experts predicting limited availability for the iPod mini. Sony's Qrio Robot will be displayed at London's best-gadget show, while virtual keyboards and MP3 players from companies like Creative, Sony, and Philips will also be on display. ...Gizmondo, a powerful gaming console with GPS and GPRS that also doubles up as an MP3 player, movie player, and camera.

granite3.1-dense:2b: This year, anticipated Christmas gift shortages stem from the high demand for popular gadgets like Apple's iPod, which is forecasted to be a top choice. The iPod mini may not suffice due to production constraints, likened to Tracey Island in a previous year's context by Oliver Irish, editor of Stuff magazine. To help consumers navigate the diverse gadget market, Stuff and What Hi-Fi? are hosting a best-of gadget show in London this weekend. Highlights include Sony's Qrio Robot, an interactive football-playing man-machine with no commercial plans for sale; a virtual keyboard that projects onto any flat surface; and the Gizmondo, a versatile gaming console with GPS, GPRS, MP3 player, movie player, and camera capabilities. Despite speculations about gaming or wireless gadgets dominating this Christmas, MP3 players remain the most sought-after stocking fillers. The event aims to demonstrate that gadgets are now lifestyle products for both men and women, emphasizing their practicality beyond being solely for tech enthusiasts.
reference: "Women will be getting gadgets from husbands and boyfriends as well as buying them for themselves," said Mr Irish.He probably has his own airplane seat, that is how highly Sony prize him," said Mr Irish."The iPod mini is likely to be this year's Tracey Island," said Mr Irish."What is impressive is how much it can do and how well it can do them," said Mr Irish."Demand is huge and Apple has promised that it can supply enough but people might struggle to get their hands on iPod minis," said Mr Irish.With Apple's iPod topping wish lists again, there may not be enough iPod minis to go round, predicts Oliver Irish, editor of gadget magazine Stuff.Stuff has compiled a list of the top 10 gadgets for 2004 and the iPod is at number one.Suggestions that it could be a gaming or wireless Christmas are unlikely to come true as MP3 players remain the most popular stocking filler, said Mr Irish.
